after my original post.

Mark

On Oct 7, 2008, at 7:58 PM, Mike Hill wrote:

> The short and sweet answer Mark is that, while someone else here may
> post a way to do it, we generally strive mightily to make our tests
> entirely independent of each other.
>
> Why not:
> public void testRegister() {
> doRegister();
> assertThings();
>
> and public void testRegisterDup() {
> doRegister();
> doRegister();
> assertThings();
>
> ?
>
> Seeya,
> Hill
>
> Going for TDD? Try <http://industriallogic.com/elearning>
>
> On Tue, Oct 7, 2008 at 12:51 PM, Mark Petrovic  
> <mspetrovic@...> wrote:
> > Good day. I am new to JUnit annotations.
> >
> > I have a need to execute a set of classic account registration  
> tests:
> > register a user by [email, password], verify that that succeeds,  
> then
> > immediately follow this with an identical registration with the same
> > [email, password], which should fail because the account already
> > exists. This is a specific case of a more general scenario where the
> > first test develops state the second test needs to know about.
> >
> > It occurred to me to use a single test class, containing two @Test-
> > decorated methods: register() and dupRegister(). The problem with
> > this structure is that I found no documentation that indicates that
> > the first decorated test method is executed after the second  
> decorated
> > test method. I also considered using the Parameter annotation, with
> > duplicate [email, password] provided as the parameter list. While
> > that could drive the tests, I see no way of indicating in this  
> scheme
> > that the first test invocation should succeed, while the second  
> should
> > fail.
> >
> > Would someone be kind enough to sketch a reasonable, "JUnit way" to
> > approach this.
> >
> > Thanks.
> >
> >
>
> 



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
